title: Valentyna Semerenko
text:
Valentyna Oleksandrivna Semerenko (), known also as Valya Semerenko () and featuring in statistics as Valj Semerenko (born 18 January 1986) is a Ukrainian <a href="Biathlon">biathlete</a>. She is <a href="Winter%20Olympics">Olympic</a> and <a href="Biathlon%20World%20Championships">World champion</a>, multiple World championships medalist and one of the most successful Ukrainian winter athletes.
Career.
When she was in the fourth grade of elementary school, she took up <a href="cross-country%20skiing">cross-country skiing</a> together with her twin sister <a href="Vita%20Semerenko">Vita</a>. But later they decided to switch to biathlon. She began competing internationally year earlier than Vita. In 2004 she took part at <a href="Biathlon%20Junior%20World%20Championships">Junior World Championships</a> in <a href="Maurienne">Maurienne</a>, <a href="France">France</a>. In 2005 she won two medals at Junior World and one at <a href="Biathlon%20European%20Championships">Junior European</a> Championships. On 17 December 2005, she debuted in <a href="Biathlon%20World%20Cup">Biathlon World Cup</a>. She finished her first World Cup sprint competition in <a href="Osrblie">Osrblie</a>, <a href="Slovakia">Slovakia</a>, ranking 47th. Valja managed to qualify for <a href="2006%20Winter%20Olympics">2006 Winter Olympics</a> where she took part only in individual race finishing 46th.
For the first time she participated at the World Championships in <a href="Biathlon%20World%20Championships%202007">2007</a> in <a href="Rasen-Antholz">Antholz-Anterselva</a>, <a href="Italy">Italy</a>. Actually, Valja missed almost the half of the <a href="2006-07%20Biathlon%20World%20Cup">2006-07 Biathlon World Cup</a>. Next season was more successful. She won the silver medal in 4×6 km relay event at the <a href="Biathlon%20World%20Championships%202008">Biathlon World Championships 2008</a>. First <a href="Biathlon%20World%20Cup">World Cup</a> relay victory came on 7 January 2009, in <a href="Oberhof%2C%20Germany">Oberhof</a>, <a href="Germany">Germany</a>.
She represented Ukraine at the <a href="2010%20Winter%20Olympics">2010 Winter Olympics</a> in <a href="Vancouver%2C%20British%20Columbia">Vancouver, British Columbia</a>, <a href="Canada">Canada</a>. In all races she placed between 13 and 23.
First individual podium Valja celebrated on 4 February 2011, in <a href="Presque%20Isle%2C%20Maine">Presque Isle</a>, <a href="United%20States">United States</a>, in sprint. At the <a href="Biathlon%20World%20Championships%202013">2013 World Championships</a> Valja won bronze in <a href="Biathlon%20World%20Championships%202013%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20individual">individual</a> race and silver in <a href="Biathlon%20World%20Championships%202013%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20relay">relay</a>. On 15 December 2013, Valja won a pursuit race in <a href="Annecy">Annecy</a>, <a href="France">France</a>, which was her first individual World Cup victory.
Together with <a href="Juliya%20Dzhyma">Juliya Dzhyma</a>, <a href="Vita%20Semerenko">Vita Semerenko</a> and <a href="Olena%20Pidhrushna">Olena Pidhrushna</a> she won the gold medal in the <a href="Biathlon%20at%20the%202014%20Winter%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20relay">Women's relay</a> at the <a href="2014%20Winter%20Olympics">2014 Winter Olympics</a>, in <a href="Sochi">Sochi</a>, <a href="Russia">Russia</a>.
<a href="2014-15%20Biathlon%20World%20Cup">2014–15 season</a> was the most successful as of January 2018. That season she had 4 individual podiums and finished third in World Cup classification, being the second ever Ukrainian biathlete to finish a season in Top-3 after <a href="Olena%20Zubrilova">Olena Zubrilova</a>. After <a href="Christmas">Christmas</a> Valja together with <a href="Serhiy%20Semenov">Serhiy Semenov</a> she won <a href="World%20Team%20Challenge">World Team Challenge</a>. The most memorable achievement was victory in <a href="Biathlon%20World%20Championships%202015%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20mass%20start">mass start</a> at <a href="Biathlon%20World%20Championships%202015">2015 World Championships</a> in <a href="Kontiolahti">Kontiolahti</a>, <a href="Finland">Finland</a>. Next two seasons weren't very successful due to illnesses and weak physical conditions. Valja was forced to miss a lot of races.
She qualified to represent <a href="Ukraine%20at%20the%202018%20Winter%20Olympics">Ukraine</a> at the <a href="2018%20Winter%20Olympics">2018 Winter Olympics</a>. Her best personal result at the Games was 19th place in mass start. She expected to run in women's relay but she wasn't included in the roster. Later she accused coaches of ignoring her results and including not so successful at the Games <a href="Iryna%20Varvynets">Iryna Varvynets</a> and <a href="Anastasiya%20Merkushyna">Anastasiya Merkushyna</a> in relay team. Her sister <a href="Vita%20Semerenko">Vita Semerenko</a> later told in an interview that Valja cried four hours after she found out that she wouldn't participate in the relay. At evening before the competition Valja posted on <a href="Facebook">Facebook</a> that "we don't have any team", "our team is just ***" and so on, and that she has something more to unveil about the team. Next day she said that she may finish her sport career immediately after the Games. Nevertheless she competed in World Cup after the Games.
Personal life.
Biathlete <a href="Vita%20Semerenko">Vita</a> is her twin sister. Valja is married to Oleksiy Prokhor. She graduated from <a href="Sumy">Sumy</a> State Pedagogical Makarenko University.
